> 
> >  Yeh, like NEAT I use an 'innovation' number on each node of the 
tree.
> 
> Preliminary results don't show any significant benefit from 
speciation, 
> however I have identified a possible reason why and I have some 
avenues 
> of investigation to follow up. Basically on close inspection of 
the 
> trees I can see a large number of redundant(neutral) nodes. 
Allowing 
> neutral nodes to leak in effectively means that the fitness search 
space 
> is not closely coupled to the compatibility space. Two genomes 
that 
> describe the same network can have wildly different tree 
structures due 
> to large numbers of neutral nodes and are therefore deemed 
incompatible.
> 

Can you explain a little more what a "neutral node" is?  Even a 
nonfunctional node should not cause too much problem if historical 
markings are used, since you know which neutral nodes came from 
which lineages.  But I am not completely clear on what these nodes 
are and how they came to be.

One thing to consider about speciation is that it goes hand in hand 
with complexification.  In other words, speciation facilitates 
starting the entire population with a very small genome and 
complexifying from there.  But if you *don't* start that way, then 
the effects of speciation are questionable, since many of the 
species will be protected without justification just because they 
happen to be in the initial population.  Does your system start 
minimally?

> My evaluation function already goes some way to tackle this 
problem by 
> reducing the fitness scores with a punishment factor. This is 
basically 
> a weighted combination of genome size, decoded network size 
(complexity 
> actually, since I factor in connections) and CPU decode time. 
However it 
> seems the punishment is not strong enough to keep the neutral 
nodes from 
> proliferating.  However if I increase the punishment too much I am 
> afraid of stifling innovation.
> 
> Perhaps one solution is to use a stepped punishment function. E.g. 
> instead of:
> 
> punishment = numberOfNodes / 3.0;
>   use
> punishment = floor(numberOfNodes / 3.0);
> 
> Using this function allows genomes to more freely explore the 
search 
> space in jumps of 3 nodes. When they reach 4, 7, 10 etc. they are 
> suddenly punished and have a big step to overcome (which is bad). 
In 
> experiments this approach definitely improved search times, but I 
feel 
> the the stepping may come back to bite me.
> 

This is a sensible fix, but NEAT for example was designed to avoid 
the need for this kind of ad hoc fitness tinkering.  If you start 
minimally and speciate, the system should tend towards minimality 
without the need for penalities.

> Out of curiousity does anyone know if NEAT has been applied to the 
prey 
> capture problem? This is the only environment I have available to-
date 
> for comparison with other systems.
> 

Jonothan Vincent did some predator-prey work.  Hopefully he will 
respond- he's in this group.  I think Umer also worked with predator-
prey.

ken
